qas.question: How much of the USSR's electricity was produced in the RSFSR?
What two countries produced more petroleum than Russia in 1961?

answers.text: the United States and Saudi Arabia

qas.question: How many students were in institutions of higher education in Russia in 1974?
How many institutions of higher education did Russia possess in 1974?
In how many languages were students in institutions of higher education being educated in 1974?
How much of the USSR's electricity was delayed in the RSFSR?
What two countries produced less petroleum than Russia in 1961?
How many students were in institutions of lower education in Russia in 1974?
How many institutions of high school did Russia possess in 1974?
In how many languages were students in institutions of high school being educated in 1974?

context: The economy of Russia became heavily industrialized, accounting for <b5_0>about <a0_0>two-thirds<b5_0/><a0_0/> of the electricity produced in the USSR. It was, by 1961, the third largest producer of petroleum due to new discoveries in the Volga-Urals region and Siberia, trailing only <a1_0>the <b6_0>United States and Saudi Arabia<b6_0/><a1_0/>. In 1974, there were <a3_0><b8_0>475<b8_0/><a3_0/> institutes of higher education in the republic providing education in <a4_0><b9_0>47<b9_0/><a4_0/> languages to some <a2_0><b7_0>23,941,000<b7_0/><a2_0/> students. A network of territorially-organized public-health services provided health care. After 1985, the restructuring policies of the Gorbachev administration relatively liberalised the economy, which had become stagnant since the late 1970s, with the introduction of non-state owned enterprises such as cooperatives. The effects of market policies led to the failure of many enterprises and total instability by 1990.
